2.text: “If one ventures a word with you, will you be wearied? Yet who can keep from speaking?

3.text: Surely you have instructed many, and have strengthened their feeble hands.

4.text: Your words have steadied those who stumbled; you have braced the knees that were buckling.

5.text: But now trouble has come upon you, and you are weary. It strikes you, and you are dismayed.

6.text: Is your reverence not your confidence, and the uprightness of your ways your hope?

7.text: Consider now, I plead: Who, being innocent, has ever perished? Or where have the upright been destroyed?

8.text: As I have observed, those who plow iniquity and those who sow trouble reap the same.

9.text: By the breath of God they perish, and by the blast of His anger they are consumed.

10.text: The lion may roar, and the fierce lion may growl, yet the teeth of the young lions are broken.

11.text: The old lion perishes for lack of prey, and the cubs of the lioness are scattered.

12.text: Now a word came to me secretly; my ears caught a whisper of it.

13.text: In disquieting visions in the night, when deep sleep falls on men,

14.text: fear and trembling came over me and made all my bones shudder.

15.text: Then a spirit glided past my face, and the hair on my body bristled.

16.text: It stood still, but I could not discern its appearance; a form loomed before my eyes, and I heard a whispering voice:

17.text: ‘Can a mortal be more righteous than God, or a man more pure than his Maker?

18.text: If God puts no trust in His servants, and He charges His angels with error,

19.text: how much more those who dwell in houses of clay, whose foundations are in the dust, who can be crushed like a moth!

20.text: They are smashed to pieces from dawn to dusk; unnoticed, they perish forever.

21.text: Are not their tent cords pulled up, so that they die without wisdom?’
